Well this week I’m full of cold, atishoo! I got this cold off all the little two and three year olds in nursery, not that I actually wanted it you understand. Of course I understand we can’t keep our children off nursery because of a snfle, butthey’ve a proper cold with coughs, sneezes and that yucky green stuff it means they are not well - not well enough to be in nursery. For just as I didn’t want this cold neither did they, but because a few decided to come in with their nasty cold germs, with the yucky green stuff, we’ve now all had it - thanks. googletag.cmd.push Of course, I understand this is not the children’s fault but, and sorry to say, it is down to those few parents who think ‘go to nursery however snotty and yucky you may be’. So I’m writing this article, for a few reasons, the first to say please do keep your child off nursery they aren’t well, it’s no fun for them and no fun for anyone  when they get the bug too. I know le can be hard with a sickly child, I know how much we need that break sometimes but please, please keep your bugs at home. googletag.cmd.push My next reason is to share with you some tips, ideas and thoughts that I’ve heard and used over the years to help with coughs, cold’s and sneezes, please do remember though I am not a doctor soyou decide to use one of these ideas that I’m passing along to you then do check with a pharmacist or doctor that is is okay to do this with your baby, toddler and  or child. . DO make your child wear a vest or t-shirt under their jumper. Believe me I have met a few children this winter who just wear t-shirts, and always look and feel cold, winter clothes are for winter and summer clothes for summe.!  . TEACH your toddler how to blow through their nose, yes literally show them how to blow, this makes runny noses so much easier to manage. Yes of course you have to hold the tissue for them, butthey can blow then that means less of the runny stuff.  . DO put a little vaseline around their noses when your little one has a cold - this stops their nose getting sore, but also makes it sooo much easier to wipe. . Do keep this little pot of vaseline just for their nose though. . TREAT, some people do use medicines, paracetamol, baby Sudafed etc and this is a personal choice, it’s up to you as parents. But as my mum said, ‘with medicine the cold will be there a week, without medicine it’ll be there for a week’. The medicines are designed to make your little one feel better, they won’t necessarily cure the cold. Remember you know your child best, whether this be they need a little something, or an appointment at the doctor.  . WHEN your little one goes to nursery do pack a spare outfit including socks, shoes or wellies and trousers - not for toilet accidents but because it is till nice to play outside but it can be wet or muddy and it is not nice to sit about later in damp clothes.  . HELP your two and three year olds learn how to blow their nose AND put the tissue in the bin not back in the box- it is a skill and does need practise but the sooner they learn the more comfortable they feel. . TEMPERATURE, a normal temperature in babies and children is about .C but this can y slightly. A fever is usually considered to be a temperatureof C or above’ . It is handy to have a thermometer at home for these worrying times - do ask for advice from a pharmacist about which is best to buy and easiest to use. But always be mindful of your little one’s temperaturethey are poorly - and especially mindful with babies.  . PLEASE don’t wipe their nose with kitchen roll - this can make it sore, use tissues with balm in them - yes I know they can be more expensive but bargain shops do great deals.Be careful wiping noses with wet wipes as some can sting - soft tissues and vaseline don’t! . EXTRA, sometimes people use a vapour, like Vicks, to rub onto their baby, toddler or child’s chest, or feet, these can be soothing when applied to the body but you can also get them as a humidier, or as an oil to pop in the bath - it’s up to you to choose what is right for your little one. Please do be aware that there are age restrictions on them and not all are suitable for all ages.  . DO make your child wear a coat and a hat for very cold weather and maybea scarf and glovesit’s very chilly.  . DON’T force your child to eat too muchthey are poorly, little and often is best, snotty noses can often lead to sickly tummy’s, but do make sure they are getting plenty of fluids so they do not become dehydrated, water, water and more water or failing that juice. . . EVEN though it’s cold outside and your little may be full of cold sometimes a walk in the fresh air for a short time can help - fresh air can make you feel better and help your little one sleep better too - just remember to wrap up warm.  . DO encourage your little one to eat lots of vegetables and fruit, all the time not just when they have a cold, these are full of vitamins that will help them to develop a good immune system. Fingers crossed these few little things help, good luck fighting the cold bug. Atishooooo! One of two men charged in connection with the rioting on the night journalist Lyra McKee was shot dead has been refused permission to go back to reside in his home.Christopher Gillen, , of Balbane Pass in Creggan, is currently on bail charged with riotous assembly, possessing and throwing petrol bombs, arson and hijacking on  April last year, the night the -year-old was shot by a New IRA gunman while watching rioting.His solicitor, Paddy MacDermott, told todays sitting of Derry Magisrates Court Gillen was applying to y his bail so he coukdto his home in Balbane Pass in Creggan.He said Gillen was currently residing with his parents in Cornshell Fields and wanted toto Creggan but police were objecting.A police officer told the court Gillen had been released on bail in November with conditions being he was not allowed to enter the Creggan area.The officer told the court an application to reduce exclusion zone to facilitate Gillens contact with his children had been granted last month.Under questioning by Mr MacDermott, the officer agreed the High Court had permitted Gillen to go in to Creggan over the Christmas period.She told the court Gillen had to travel in and out of the area and there had been no issues.Mr MacDermott told the court the application should be granted as the defendant had been in Creggan at Christmas.He said “the natural place for him to be is in his own home” as the exclusion zone was causing dficulty in the day-to-day care of his children.The solicitor said there was no reason why Gillen could not be allowed back to Creggan and added there had been no public disorder in that area since October.District Judge Barney McElholm said: It is getting very close to something andthe media are to be believed, and there is no reason why not, there are plans for all sorts of triumphalist demonstrations.He refused the application and Gillen will appear again on  February. googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us Access to one of Inishowens most popular beaches has been restricted. Donegal County Council closed off the road to Lisfannon beach after signicant damage was caused due to the effects of Storm Brendan and ongoing erosion.Councillor Jack Murray said: “Unfortunately the road at Lisfannon Beach has endured signicant flood damage in recent days. “The council has responded and fenced off the immediate area for safety reasons. “Further to that, I have asked that it is cleaned up and repaired as soon as possible. There is some dficulty however in completing lasting repairs to the road as flood damage is a recurring problem with the location being very exposed to the elements. “The council will however liaise with all relevant statutory agencies with the aim of developing a lasting solution to this problem.“This is hugely important for the local community as Lisfannon Beach is an extremely popular tourist amenity and is much loved by local and visitors alike. googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Organisers of what has been described as a “magical evening” in Derry city centre have spoken of their pride at how the local community supported an event aimed a easing the lives of those in the city facing hardship.Derry has always been known as a city that comes together when times are hard. A city that shows fantastic community spirit. The night of  December was no dferent. That was the night a group of local artists decided to give something back and did so by way of a “site specic performance” of a new drama performed on the Guildhall steps to an overwhelming audience of support. Brief Synopsis: Closed Shutters is a tragic comedy full with social commentary, spoken in a Derry voice but has a global resonance. It is a story of three homeless alcoholics, set at the mouth of Christmas and takes place over  hours in their lives.The creative decision was made to perform the piece outside, as the team wanted the story to resonate with the audience. Let them feel the cold. This is what is faced by many people on our streets nightly.  Preparations began in September, with the assembly of the creative team and rehearsals. From the very beginning, everyone involved in the production made a collective decision to waive any fees. Everyone devoted their time and energy for nothing in order to give as much back to the community as possible. googletag.cmd.push  PICTURED: Presentation of cheques to Derry Well Woman, Foyle Food Bank and North West Methodist Mession. Call outs went out on social media asking for donations of cold weather items hats, coats, scarves, gloves, blankets, sleeping bags… the list goes on. As well as the physical items, the team set up a gofundme page to raise money. They were not expecting the response they got! In the lead up to the event, as word started to spread about what was happening, the donations began… and they didn’t stop.The team reached out to the North West Methodist Mission first and were delighted when they agreed to come on board and help out, donating pound worth of brand new sleeping bags, all to be distributed to the homeless. As well as this, they provided all of the props needed and transport on the day. By way of a thank you for their kindness, North West Methodist Mission then received  bags of cold weather gear, as well as bags of food, toys and blankets. All of which went straight to those in need. A gofundme page raised pound which, in turn, was given to the North West Methodist Mission, to repay the investment they had made in the project, plus some extra. On the day of the performance, volunteers gathered around the city centre with collection buckets, while others gathered bags of cold weather items in the Guildhall. The total raised on the night was pound, which was then split between and recently presented to two local charities who do great work within the city - Derry Well Woman and Foyle Food Bank receiving pound. JP Conaghan, director, said: “To say the support was overwhelming is an understatement. The people showed up and witnessed our gt. They humbled me to a level words cannot describe. I want to say a massive GRMA agus GRAacute MOacuteR to each and every one who donated so kindly a week before Christmas.” The team have extended a heartfelt and huge thank you to everyone who supported the project in any way, whether that be by donation or by turning up on the night and sitting through the cold and wet air to watch the performance. Fiona McLaughlin, pro- ducer, said: “We cannot thank everyone enough. We never thought we could have this much of an impact. It just goes to show you what can be donewe all give a little of our time to those less fortunate. Derry City you are beautul! Although the project may have come to an end, the homeless epidemic in our city has not. Don’t let this be the end.Andrew Doherty, writer, said: “With Small charitable acts of kindness, we as a community avoid falling into the pitfalls which are destroying our community. Together we raised pound,, and hopefully through word of mouth, social media and mediums like this, the project can continue to make a dference and the pos- sibilities are endless.” googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. A new car lt will be installed at the vehicle testing centre in New- buildings as soon as possible to help MOTs get underway again, it has been announced.Minister forInfrastructure, Nicola Mallon, confirmed the installationof the lt was being “accelerated” following the suspension of tests for cars and light vehicles on Tuesday.The suspension came after cracks were discoveredin  of the  car lts in MOT centres throughout the North.Minister Mallon said:“I have already said that I want to see urgent progress on carrying out MOT testsand I am pleased to confirm that two new lts are being installed to provide additional capacity – one in Belfast and one in Newbuildings, Derry.These lts were pre- ordered at the end of  as part of a programme to increase capacity within the testing network.Their deployment has now been accelerated due to the current disruption.These lts will be independently inspected and checked before becoming operational. More information will follow on when and how these two new lts will be operational but I expect that to be possible within the next few days.Cars or light vehicles which are five years old or more are eligible for a temporary exemption certicate, which will extend a vehicles MOT certicate by four months.However, four-year-old cars have never been tested and are, therefore, not eligible for the exemption.“I have instructed the DVA that they are to be focussed on testing taxis and four-year-old cars for private customers and also car dealerships in the first instance, said Mrs Mallon.I have also instructed the DVA to speak with the Federation for Small Businesses to ensure clear communication is being delivered. I have already ensured that all other customers can be covered by the issue of temporary exemption certicates.“My Department is not responsible for the clamping of vehicles, that is the DVLA. However, the DVA has communicated to the DVLA that customers unable to tax their vehicles due to this disruption should not be penalised.“I will continue to push the DVA for progress on increasing the capacity for testing, whilst ensuring that safety remains the top priority for customers and staff.”Meanwhile, Derry MLA Raymond McCartney suggested four-year-old cars could be given a one year extension to alleviatewaiting times.“Sinn Feacutein have raised the possibility of providing a one year extension on the requirement for four-year-old cars to get tested.This would free up testing lanes for taxis.“I welcome the independent investigation ordered by the Minister for Infrastructure to examine how this situation arose.“We need to get to the bottom of these problems to address the health and safety concerns of workers and drivers alike. The Minister also needs to directly address the capacity issues plaguing the DVA.“This should include exploring a similar testing regime used in the south for private cars between four and -years-old which are tested every two years - as opposed to yearly.“This could alleviate a lot of serious pressures on MOT centres. googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. title: £13m upgrade in water treatment at Drumaroad
story: WORK is underway on a poundm investment at the Drumaroad water treatment plant.The major scheme is designed to improve the security of the water supply at the facility near Castlewellan with work on the project expected to be completed next spring.The Drumaroad plant treats water from the Silent Valley reservoir in the heart of the Mournes which delivers around  million litres of water every day to over , homes across Co Down and Belfast.New Stormont infrastructure minister, Nichola Mallon, said the poundm upgrade highlights the impact investment in the water infrastructure can have.She revealed that once complete, the Drumaroad investment will have a ldquopositive impact on the lives of up to , people mdash a quarter of the Northern Ireland population mdash who can benefit from increased resilience and security of the water supply, particularly in emergency situations. This will make a real dference to peoplersquos daily lives.Paul Davison, head of water capital procurement at NI Water, said the organisation is delighted that work on the poundm Drumaroad project is underway, explaining that it will bring many improvements to customers, including improved security of the water supply.ldquoThe services NI Water provides are at the very core of the economy, health and environment of Northern Ireland, he continued.ldquoThis key investment will help us to continue to deliver a world-class water service to Belfast and Co Down and protect our most valuable and precious asset, water.NI Water says that the Drumaroad investment is an example of what can be done with sufficient investment in the water and wastewater infrastructure where in Northern Ireland.It confirmed that its total investment in the local authority area between  and next year will be almost poundm, with bids to invest just over poundm in the area between  and .NI Water says that this level of investment is required to maintain and keep the existing water and wastewater assets in the council area running and to address identied capacity and potential environmental issues.Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairman Charlie Casey welcomed the major investment.ldquoThe investment will greatly improve services for customers throughout Co Down and Belfast and I am impressed to see the extent of the improvements which will bring great benefits to the water infrastructure throughout the North of Ireland, he added.Graham Construction is the main contractor with RPS providing project management and technical support..prettyPhoto

title: Charity head shave in aid of Guide Dogs for the Blind
story: A LOCAL politician is having his head shaved this weekend to help a Ballynahinch schoolgirlrsquos fundraising initiative on behalf of the Guide Dogs for the Blind Association.Rowallane councillor Billy Walker will have his locks shaved off this Saturday by  year-old Sophie Mills who is a student at Ballynahinch High School.She has been diagnosed with Albinism mdash which affects her eyesight mdash and is currently on the waiting list for a guide dog.Sophie has previously been cane trained by representatives from the charity and is hoping that she can get a guide dog soon as in dull or very bright lighting conditions she finds it hard to see.Over the past two years, she has completely lost her sight six times and had no vision for the first six months of her le.The teenagerrsquos fundraising efforts were recently recognised in a province-wide SuperValu competition for those who go beyond the call of duty to help others in need. And, while keen to get her own dog, Sophie is also raising money to help others get the guide dog they need.Despite a growing concern that her eye condition is deteriorating, Sophie has her sights firmly set on helping others.Given that it costs pound, to train a guide dog, Sophie is determined to do all that she can to help both herself and others. She said thatshe had a guide dog of her own, it would give her so much confidence.Sophie, who in the past has helped sponsor guide dogs for others who need them, is holding a fundraising event in Ballynahinch Masonic Hall this Saturday evening which starts at .pm.She is selling raffle tickets for a host of prizes ahead of the fundraiser with Cllr Walkerrsquos head shave taking place earlier in the day at Ballynahinch Market House. He is due to have his locks shaved at am.Cllr Walker says he is more than happy to have his head shaved to raise money on behalf of Sophie, even though itrsquos still winter and he will have to wear a hat for a few weeks.He added: ldquoI hope to raise as much as I can and I am encouraging people to give generously to support Sophie. My fundraising target is pound.Admission to the event is pound. The winners of the ious raffle prizes will be drawn on the night by Sophie..prettyPhoto

title: Clive travels around island visiting Church of Ireland cathedrals
story: A KILLYLEAGH man has completed a personal pilgrimage of Church of Ireland cathedrals in Ireland.Clive Scoularrsquos journey began in  and ended in October last year when he visited his th and final cathedral in Cashel, Co Tipperary.Now hersquos shared his experiences in a new book, Cathedral Odyssey mdash a journey through Irelandrsquos Anglican cathedrals and beyond, which has just been published.Itrsquos the th book to be written by the retired social worker and keen historian.His previous books include biographies of two former Northern Ireland prime ministers, a collection of biographies of famous Irishmen and Irishwomen, the history of the Europa Hotel in Belfast and six famous sons of Killyleagh, including Sir Hans Sloane and footballer David Healy.Born in Scotland of Presbyterian heritage, Clive has been a member of the congregation at Down Cathedral for many years. He is a former member of the cathedral choir and was also a member of the choir at St Annersquos Cathedral in Belfast.He says his love of cathedrals began when he attended a service in St Maryrsquos Episcopal Cathedral in Glasgow while training to become a social worker.ldquoI just loved everything about it mdash the service, the music, the atmosphere. It all made sense, he explains.Cliversquos cathedral tour coincided with another long standing ambition mdash to play every golf course in Ireland. Travelling by camper van, hersquos played  courses to date and also written a book about it.Clive is at pains to point out that he didnrsquot just visit the cathedrals mdash he also attended a service in every one of them. Asked which was hisfavourite, he is undecided, though some stand out more than others.ldquoThe cathedrals are so dferent, so itrsquos dficult to say which was the nicest or the most impressive. I really liked some of the small ones, such as in Trim, Co Meath, Ferns in Co Waterford and Raphoe in Donegal, he says.ldquoThe bigger ones, such as in Kilkenny and Kildare, were very impressive and I really liked the visit to Rosscarbery Cathedral in Co Cork.ldquoKilmore Cathedral outside Cavan town is also lovely. Itrsquos the only building in sight and is tucked away in the trees. There was a large congregation, including around  children.At Killala Cathedral in Mayo, Clive met up with Archdeacon Stephen McWhirter, an old friend from his Scouting days.Clive says his visit to Cashel in October was memorable for another reason. ldquoI had emailed in advance explaining that I had visited all the Church of Ireland cathedrals in Ireland and asked them for the time of the service. When we got there we were treated like royalty.Cliversquos fascination with cathedrals isnrsquot limited to Ireland. He has also visited cathedrals in Malta, Gibraltar, South Africa, New Zealand, Canada and the United States.Cliversquos book costs pound and is available by contacting him at clive.scoular@gmail..prettyPhoto

title: Devlin delivers as Forest thrive
story: AFTER last weekrsquos Harry Clarke Cup mauling at the hands of the Olympic second string, Forest found the Ballynahinch thirds team much more to their liking when they enjoyed a - victory at Bear Park.In a surprisingly entertaining game, both teams had half chances in the first few minutes with Olympicrsquos Damian Travers and Dylan McCartan unable to get shots on target.Forest should have taken the lead in the ninth minute when a Paul Kane corner kick was only cleared as far as Philly Flood, and his cross just evaded Ray Kendall who was sliding in at the back post.This was to be Floodrsquos last meaningful contribution to the game as he went over on his ankle and had to be replaced by McKibbin, with Jennings ping into left back.Tollymore started with almost the same team that was beaten last week with the exception of Paul Devlin, who was making his debut, and Mooney, Flood, and Paul Kane who were all unavailable last week.However, it was Devlin that made the dference in the first  minutes.The midfielder almost opened the scoring after  minutes when his sizzling free kick from the edge of the penalty area warmed the hands of lsquokeeper Dean Blackwood with Paul Kane heading the loose ball wide.Moments later a huge clearance from Tollymore lsquokeeper Imrie bounced over the Olympic defence, and Rory Walsh jumped with Blackwood only to see his header go wide of the target.Just as it seemed neither team was going to score, Devlin hit a wonder goal from  yards, with the power and swerve of the shot leaving Blackwood flat-footed.With the wind at their backs Tollymore stepped things up and in the th minute an astute pass from Kane picked out Rory Walsh who hit the Olympic crossbar.Devlin was replaced at half-time by Marty McCourt for his first game since early September, and while the big man looked rusty, he soon picked up the pace of the game.Both sides had half chances before Forest doubled their advantage in the th minute when a through ball from Kane saw Walsh nipping in behind the Olympic defence.The unlucky Stephen McConnell barged Walsh in the back with the striker tumbling into the advancing lsquokeeper and referee Mullan had no hesitation in awarding a sport kick.Paul Kane stepped up to take the penalty and lsquoThe Generalrsquo made no mistake to score his second goal in two games.Forest now started to take control and a terric run from James Jennings saw Maxwell and McConnell combining well to scramble the ball clear.In the st minute Walsh made the score - when he ran onto a pass from Marty McCourt to shoot past Blackwood.Forest replaced Kane with Matt McCormick and the young striker almost scored immediately, but was denied by an excellent save from Blackwood whose out-stretched leg prevented a certain goal.In the th minute McCormick did find the net after some excellent approach play from Burkowski.Moments later a superb run from Olympicrsquos Thomas Rogers almost ended with a deserved goal, but his shot flashed over the Forest crossbar.A good performance from Tollymore that resulted in a deserved win, but can they repeat the performance this weekend as consistency is whatrsquos important Best for Tollymore were James Jennings and a remarkable first half performance from Paul Devlin, but in truth it was a good team performance.Match sponsor: Diamond Patrsquos, Newcastle.Tollymore Forest Ballynahinch Olympic III NEWCASTLE LEAGUE DIVISION .prettyPhoto

title: Flagship Festival of Flight set to return
story: IT has been confirmed that the Festival of Flight will be ing to Newcastle in June.Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos flagship tourist event will take place on Saturday, June .This festival, which comprises exciting displays both on and off the ground is expected to attract tens of thousands of visitors to the resort.It has not yet been confirmedthe RAF Red Arrows display team will be taking part.The Festival of Flight is part of the councilrsquos lsquoGiant Adventuresrsquo programme of events which was announced this week.They include Wake the Giant in Warrenpoint in August, and Footsteps in the Forest in Slieve Gullion Forest Park.The Councilrsquos tourism programme will also include the DownTime Festival in Downpatrick from June -, the Strangford Lough Skfie Festival from July -August , and the Strangford Lough and the Narnia Festival in Kilbroney Park, Rostrevor, from November -.Council chairman Charlie Casey said: ldquoThese flagship festivals are key events in our programme of tourism events.ldquoWe are very pleased that the Festival of Flight, Wake the Giant and Footsteps in the Forest are all scheduled toto our district in .ldquoThese festivals act as a catalyst to inspire visitors to visit our area. Investing in these key events, demonstrates the huge commitment that our council makes to attract visitors to experience the beauty of our landscape and coastline.Cllr Casey added: ldquoThe theme of our Giant Adventures demonstrates the scale of our ambition to host world-class events in our district.ldquoEach of these events are held at key locations within our area and I look forward to watching these events continue to evolve and extend the visitor season..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C January 29%2C 1980
story: DUNDRUM mdash Anger is mounting in Dundrum over whether a section of a lane in the village, which has been used by generations of adults and children, should remain open.Residents are beginning to band together in an attempt to keep the lane a right of way. They claim the current owner has plans to have part of it closed.The lane in question virtually transverses theof the village, from near the police barracks through to Flynnrsquos, but the section which is causing concern among residents is between Castle Hill and its junction with the Dromara Road.Residents say the people for Dundrum always regarded this lane as a right of way, but that the owner of a caravan site in the area intends to close it.A Recorder reporter went along to the lane and interviewed several residents on the subject. Each was adamant that the lane should remain a right of way.Local councillor, Mr Jarlath Carey, said many people had expressed their concern at the possible erection of gates on the lane. He said the lane had been used for many years by a wide iety of people.ldquoFarmers, nearby residents going to church, children going to school and people out walking enjoying the countryside will all be affectedit is closed, he said.ldquoIt provides a safe and direct route for children going and coming from school and means they can avoid the busy main street.BALLYNAHINCH mdash Work has begun on a new pound, factory in Ballynahinch which will bring  new jobs when it is completed in the summer. The premises are being erected for the thriving Pinewick firm and is believed to be the first cane furniture manufacturing factory in Ireland.Work started on clearing the Magheraknock Road site let weekend and it is hoped that foundations for the , sq ft factory will be laid on Monday.At the moment Pinewick employ  people in a small workshop in the town, where all their goods are manufactured. They are then distributed to Pinewick shops in Ballynahinch, Belfast, Ballymoney and at the Co-Op in Belfast.Such has been the demand in both retail and wholesale that expansion was necessary. Accordingly, Pinewick purchased the site at Magheraknock Road and, providing there are no hold-ups, they will be offering  much-needed jobs in the summer.SAINTFIELD mdash The closure of Saintfieldrsquos McCleery and LrsquoAmie factory with the loss of  jobs has sent shockwaves through the area. The company blames over-capacity in the industry and intense competition from countries such as Taiwan and South Korea.The closure comes as a big shock, with the company active in the last few months liaising with the Department of Commerce to find a workable solution.A spokesman for the company said this week that it had become increasingly unprofitable to manufacture and sell the high bulk acrylic yarn in which the factory had dealt mainly.The future prospects for this field of operation did not justy new capital investment despite substantial assistance from government in the form of capital grants, the spokesman added.The closure continues a black period for the area on the industrial front, with  jobs being lost at Ballygowan and then  laid off at Castlewellan.KILLYLEAGH mdash A Killyleagh man was guest of honour at a special presentationin Belfast on Saturday night. Colonel James Cunningham, from Ballytrim, was presented his portrait in oils to mark the th anniversary of the regiment of which he is president.Col Cunningham led the Belfast Heavy Anti-Aircraft Regiment on the Royal Artillery Supplementary Reserve in Burma in World War  and has been the Association president since its formation after the war.CARRYDUFF mdash USPCA workers at the animal shelter in Carryduff have launched a new appeal this week mdash a home for the donkey which nobody seems to want.Earlier this week they asked the owner of the piebald donkey found wandering on lands at Clough to get in touch with them. He did and he told them he was not interested in taking the wayward donkey back because he had too much trouble with it.And so the shelter have launched this latest appeal for a new owner. ldquoAlthough he has been causing a shelter problem and has some bad habits, he is quite an attractive donkey and would be ideal for anyone prepared to work with him, a shelter spokesman explained.DOWNPATRICK mdash A Downpatrick councillor is waging a one-man campaign to clean up Down District. Mr George Flinn is trying to draw attention to illegal dumping along roadsides and believes his fellow councillors are not doing enough to stamp out the problem.His first step came last week when, with some dficulty, he persuaded councillors to enter Down District in the  Keep Britain Tidy competition. However, there was a noticeable lack of enthusiasm on the part of most councillors and no final decision has been reached.Many councillors feel that the district is in such an appalling state that they could be embarrassed at the results of the competition.MOURNES mdash A  year-old schoolgirl who collapsed from the early stages of exhaustion in the Mourne Mountains on Tuesday was brought down safely by rescue teams.The girl was one of a party of ten Belfast schoolchildren with two instructors and she collapsed on the Brandy Pad, near Harersquos Gap. One instructor and the remainder of the group were taken back to a rendezvous point where they raised the alarm.The Mourne Mountain Rescue Team set out immediately to the girlrsquos assistance, but on their way up the mountain met the girl and the instructor in the company of two climbers. She had recovered sufficiently to walk with help.After a hot shower and some hot food at the NI Mountain Centre, they were staying, the girl soon recovered.KILLOUGH mdash Mid-summer should see work commence on a new sewerage scheme for the village of Killough.The Department of the Environment project involves the construction of a new sewage treatment works and outfall and the construction of new gravity sewers, pumping station and pumping mains.The scheme will replace the existing raw sewage outfalls. The new treatment works and outfall will be located some distance from the village.PORTAFERRY mdash A project by pupils at St Columbarsquos High School in Portaferry won praise in the recent Aer Lingus-sponsored Young Scientists exhibition.The project drew the attention of the judges who gave a highly commended verdict and awarded a certicate of merit to the school, as well an engraved pen to each group member.The schoolrsquos project was to discover which areas of the electromagnetic spectrum were most beneficial to plant development. From the results of the research, the group found that the red end of the spectrum was best, while ultra-violet radiation killed them.The group consisted of Michael McGovern, Mary Bryce, Bernadette McNamara and Anne Marie Lynch, under the supervision of Mr P Hanna and Mr R Bradley.CASTLEWELLAN mdash Five sheep were killed and a further  injured when dogs attacked flocks of sheep in the Castlewellan area on Monday night.Mr Patrick McDowell, of Burrenbane, who has land taken in Burrenbridge, had four sheep killed and three injured. Mr James McCartan, of Lower Burren Road, had one killed and eight injured.Police, who are investigating the attacks, have appealed to dog owners to ensure their animals are kept under control.SPA mdash Spa Young Farmersrsquo Club held its annual gentsrsquo night recently when the venue was Ballynahinch Rugby Club for a meal and disco. Miss Caroline Dodds, a former member, was responsible for the catering..prettyPhoto

title: Hat trick of titles for Paul as Spa bowlers dominate
story: THE Mid Down Zone Bowls finals were played last Friday night in Killinchy.Eight clubs were represented in the finals with the winners going on to represent Mid Down Zone at Shawrsquos Bridge in the Irish finals in March.This year the honours were well distributed with Paul McNamara claiming three Mid Down titles while club mates Don McNamara, Colin Wilson and Alan Laughlin claiming two titles.NationalsLast yearrsquos winners Rose Marie Wylie, Robin Horner, Graham Christie and Peter Christie of Spa Golf Club played club mates Colin Wilson, Don McNamara, Paul McNamara and Alan Laughlin in the National Fours final.Alan took an early lead forging - ahead after four ends. Peter scored three shots on the fth end to put his rink right back in the game. Two ends later the scores were level at  all. Alan scored one shot on the eighth end to set up a tense final end. After a great last end Peter just failed to get the shot with his last bowl to leave Alanrsquos rink winners by -.The National Triples final was again an all Spa GC affair between holders Robin Horner, Graham Christie and Peter Christie and Colin Wilson, Paul McNamara and Alan Laughlin. After three ends Peter had romped into a - lead. However, four shots to Alan on the fourth end changed the complexion of the match.Peter led - going into the ninth end, but Alan managed to secure the shot to send the match into a tie end. Peter hit the end with his last bowl and when the dust settled an umpire was called to decide who lay the shot. After some deliberation the shot was awarded to Alanrsquos triple.The National Pairs final was an all Spa GC affair between Don and Paul McNamara and Robin Horner and Adam Gilmour.The McNamaras got off to a flyer, leading - after two ends. Robin and Adam edged their way back into the game and were - in arrears after five ends.The next end proved the turning point as Paul trailed the jack for four shots. Two shots were exchanged on ends seven and eight to leave Paul - ahead with two ends to go. Even though Robin and Alan scored two shots on the ninth end it wasnrsquot enough as Don and Paul won -. Both pairs qualy for the Irish finals in March.The singles final was between Tony Ward from St Maryrsquos Killyleagh and Spa Golf Clubrsquos Robin Horner.Tony led - after two ends. Robin then won three ends in a row to level matters at  all. The sixth end proved to be pivotal as Tony collected four shots. Robin then scored two singles before Tony scored a single on the ninth end to lead -.Robin tried his best on the last end but could only muster two shots to fall just one shot short. Both players have qualied for the Irish finals.LadiesrsquoThe Ladies Triples final was contested between Helen Hanley, Marie Geddis and Albina Black of Killinchy and Saintfield BCrsquos Joan Gamble, Ann Jordan and Elsie Alexander. Albinarsquos triple dominated from the off leading - after five ends. Two shots to Elsie on ends six and seven just left her two shots behind.Albina then scored two shots on the eighth end giving her triple a four shot cushion going into the last end. This proved to be too big a mountain to climb as Elsie was only able to lt one shot to leave Albina - ahead.Mary Brown and Sally Seaton of Comber BC played Killinchyrsquos Marie Geddis and Albina Black in the Ladies Pairs final.The Comber pair took control of the game leading - after five ends. Killinchy ladies mounted a comeback in the second half of the game and trailed - going into the last end. They were laying two shots for a tie end, but Sally played a brilliant bowl to get the shot for an - win.In the Ladies Singles final Meghan McCabe from St Maryrsquos, Killyleagh, played Linda Vance of Kilmore Presbyterians.This was an intriguing affair with the lead changing on several occasions. Meghan scored one shot on the opening end before ping two shots on the second end. She then collected three shots before Linda scored four shots to take a - lead.Meghan then scored five shots over the next two ends to lead -. Linda, however, won the last four ends to take the ladies singles title by -.Over  PairsCyril Cromie and Don McNamara, of Spa GC, played William Bassett and Eileen Green, of Ballycruttle, in the Over  Pairs final.Eileen dominated from the off and opened up a - lead after six ends. Cyril and Don found their form in the final five ends, but could not close the gap as William and Eileen had two shots to spare at the end.JuniorsThe U- Singles was played between Daniel Spratt, from Kilmore Presbyterian and Hayden Tumelty, from Ballycruttle. Daniel gave an impressive display of bowling racing into an - lead after five ends.Hayden took the next two ends to reduce the deficit to eight shots, but Daniel took the last three ends to win -. In the U- Pairs final Robert Horner and Jason Hamilton, from First Comber, defeated the young pair of Annie and Aidan Scarlett, from Saintfield BC.The Comber pair raced into an - lead after five ends, but the Scarletts fought back in the second half of the game to end up - behind.A lovely supper was supplied and served by the Committee and a collection was taken up for this yearrsquos charity which is MITRE Trust Musgrave Park Hospital a sum of pound was collected..prettyPhoto

title: I’m grateful above all to God and to the work of his grace
story: THE new Church of Ireland Bishop of Down and Dromore has been ordained. The Right Rev David McClay mdash who succeeds Bishop Harold Miller mdash was formally ordained at a special service in St Annersquos Cathedral, Belfast, last weekend.The cathedral was filled to capacity as Bishop McClay was ordained by the Archbishop of Armagh, the Most Rev Dr Richard Clarke.Family members, representatives from the parishes of the diocese, friends and colleagues made the journey from all over Ireland, England and the United States for the service.The Dean of Connor, the Very Rev Sam Wright, gave the address in which he recalled how he and Bishop McClay began theological college together  years ago and quickly became friends.Turning to the question of what the new bishop was to do, Dean Wright took  Corinthians :- as his text and the inspiration of a lsquobrave, bright and beautul gospelrsquo.He said: ldquoIt is clear from past experience that David will do many things, but I want to encourage him to keep to the main thing mdash to share the Good News of Jesus.ldquoAnd as the chief shepherd for the people of Down and Dromore Diocese to encourage, enable and equip the church, to bring this Good News to the world. In this era of scepticism and rejection by many of the Christian Gospel, he will need to be Brave, and to offer a Bright and Beautul Gospel to all.Dean Wright said that in both his le and in his sharing of Christ, the new bishop had ldquocourageously sought to change lives through his teaching and explanation of the word of God and through the power of the Holy Spirit.ldquoDavid has been a champion for the poor. He has spoken out against violence when it would have been easier to stay silent. Paulrsquos words in  Corinthians : are as true today as ever mdash lsquoThe god of this age has blinded the minds of unbelievers, so that they cannot see light of the gospel.rsquo It takes courage to shine out the gospel into the darkness of the world. David, in your new role, be brave.The Dean reminded the congregation that the ordination was taking place on the Feast Day of the Conversion of St Paul.Addressing the bishop-elect he said: ldquoAs you find yourself dealing with the people and issues of a large diocese, recall your own conversion experience and how Godrsquos bright light broke into the darkness of your le. Flooding peoplersquos lives with the hope found in the good news of the gospel, bringing out the God-colours into the world.That is to be your primary aim as a Bishop.The sermon was followed by the Rite of Ordination and for the ordination prayer and laying on of hands, Archbishop Clarke was joined by other bishops, the Methodist President and former Presidents.The new bishop was then vested in his robes and given a Bible before being presented to the congregation who greeted him with loud, sustained applause. The Dean of Belfast, the Very Rev Stephen Forde, then installed Bishop McClay in his cathedral stall.At the reception which followed in Ulster Universityrsquos Birley Building, Bishop McClay expressed his thanks to all those who had taken part in the service, his parents and family and the many people who had travelled a distance to be there.Bishop McClay said he looked forward to building on the work of two predecessors, Bishop Harold Miller and Bishop Gordon McMullan, who he had been ldquoprivileged to serve under.He added: ldquoIrsquom very grateful for all that they have put in place by way of a heritage to build upon. But Irsquom grateful above all to God and to the work of his grace.Among the dignitaries and Church leaders who attended the service were Her Majestyrsquos Lord Lieutenant of Belfast, Fionnuala Jay-OrsquoBoyle the President of the Methodist Church in Ireland, Revd Sam McGuffin the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Armagh, the Most Rev Eamon Martin the Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in Ireland, the Rt Rev Dr William Henry the Bishop of Down and Connor, the Most Rev Noel Treanor the former Suffragan Bishop in the Diocese of the Arctic, the Right Rev Darren McCartney the Bishop of Albany, the Right Rev William Love and representatives from the Benedictine Community of the Holy Cross Monastery in Rostrevor..prettyPhoto

title: Mash Direct secures £10m financial boost
story: CO Down food firm Mash Direct has unveiled plans to increase production capacity to meet growing demand for its products, following a poundm funding package from HSBC UK.The sixth-generation family business mdash which specialises in processed vegetables mdash will use HSBC UKrsquos support to make its custom-built, on-farm production facility in Comber more environmentally friendly.The firm supplies supermarket chains such as Tesco, Sainsbury, Asda, Waitrose, Co-Op, Aldi, Lidl and Dunnes. In , Mash Direct products were also sold in the United States for the first time.New solar and wind energy machinery will be installed at its Ballyrainey Road base along with a new wastewater treatment facility, helping to future-proof the business by reducing its carbon footprint and making the overall plant more sustainable.In addition, Mash Direct will also increase its capacity for growth by adding new production lines to its industrial kitchen so that it can produce new dishes and increase production capacity.And the business will also be adding a new onion peeler that will free up space in its peeling area alongside plans to invest in robotics and enterprise management software.Mash Direct will employ  new staff to support its growth, with the roles ranging from operations and management to sales, marketing, exports and human resources.The firm is also investing in a robust training programme to up-skill its existing team.Mash Direct chief operating officer Jack Hamilton explained that with growing demand for its range of products at home and abroad, it was essential that it invested in new, environmentally friendly machinery and in the talented, skilled staff it currently has.He added: ldquoImproving our carbon footprint is very important to the business and great strides will be made to do this with our investment in new technology.ldquoHSBC UK shares our vision for growth and understands our immediate needs as a rapidly scaling SME in the agri-foods sector.HSBC UKrsquos relationship director in Northern Ireland, Marty Colvin, described Mash Direct as an ldquoexciting and ambitious business operating in a highly competitive and thriving sector.He added: ldquoThe improvements the company is making to its farming operations with HSBC UKrsquos support will stand it in good stead as it aims to grow its market share and meet demand from customers across the UK and overseas..prettyPhoto

title: McCabe point saves blushes in Tipperary
story: DOWN didnrsquot really enjoy the lsquoTrip to Tipprsquo on Sunday when they could only manage a draw in a disappointing start to their Division  campaign.Paddy Tallyrsquos side trailed - to - at the break, but a rsquo from goalkeeper Rory Burns brought the sides level just after the restart.Tipperary were then reduced to  men when Jack Kennedy was yellow carded and as he had already been sin-binned in the first half , he was shown a red card.Alas, Down were unable to take use of their numerical advantage and only managed another three points over the next  minutes to leave Clonmel Sportsfield with a share of the spoils.Down opened in a hurry with Donal OrsquoHare converting an early free, but the reliable Conor Sweeney brought the sides level, also from a free. OrsquoHare, Barry OrsquoHagan and Cory Quinn helped Down seize control with points apiece, but Sweeney left two points in it when he scored from play in the th minute, - to -.Another OrsquoHare extended Downrsquos lead to three points in the th minute, but this was to be their last score of the half as Tipperary hit back.Unanswered points from goalkeeper Evan Comerford, Liam Boland and Sweeney gave the hosts a deserved - to - led a the break.Burns and Kennedy swapped scores at the start of the second half, but the Tipperary ace then saw red after receiving his second card of the game.Tipp were now up against it, but Down were unable to shake them off.Points from Owen McCabe and Pat Havern were cancelled out by similar scores from Sweeneyand Comerford as Tipp held a - to - lead with seven minutes remaining.Down refused to relent and piled on the pressure as Tipp started to wilt. A Burns rsquo was added to by a great score from Carryduffrsquos Owen McCabe, but a winner could just not come.Down huffed and puffed, but were unable to breach the Tipp defence again and in the final analysis, the home side were the happier, given they played for most of the second half with  men.Tipperary: Evan Comerford , Alan Campbell, John Meagher, Colm OrsquoShaughnessy, Emmet Moloney, Robbie Kiely, Daacuteire Brennan, Steven OrsquoBrien , Conal Kennedy, Bill Maher, Jack Kennedy , Kevin Fahey , Conor Sweeney , Brian Fox. Subs: Kevin OrsquoHalloran for Fahey, Jason Lonergan for Boland Tommy Noland for Conal Kennedy, Colman Kennedy for Maher.Down: Rory Burns , Peter Fegan, Kevin McKernan, Ryan McAleenan, Gerard Collins, Darren OrsquoHagan, Shane Annett, Conor Maginn, Sean Dornan, Barry OrsquoHagan , Conor Poland, Daniel Guinness, Owen McCabe , Donal OrsquoHare , Cory Quinn . Subs: Pat Havernfor Dornan, Liam Kerr for Maginn, Niall Donnelly for Poland, Ross McGarry for Guinness, Johnny Flynn for B OrsquoHagan.Tipperary -Down -ALLIANZ NFL DIVISION .prettyPhoto

title: Meeting sought with new health minister
story: HOSPITAL campaigners are seeking an early meeting with new Stormont health minister Robin Swann.The meeting with the new man at the helm of the Department of Health is one of a number campaigners are seeking in the near future, with invitations for talks also to be extended to senior officials from the South Eastern Trust and the Ambulance Service.Last weekrsquos meeting of the Down Community Health Committee was the first to be held since the restoration of the Stormont Executive and the publication of the lsquoNew Decade New Approachrsquo document which outlines the key priorities moving forward.Chief among these is health and social services, with campaigners keen to see a commitment to equality of access to healthcare services for those who live in rural communities in particular.Campaigners say they are pleased that health and social care will continue to be a priority within the programme for government and that there will be a greater focus on mental health and well-being which has not been the case in the past.At last weekrsquos meeting, it was suggested that the New Decade New Approach document raises what have been described as ldquofundamental challenges for politicians in terms of their capacity to deliver.Campaigners say that there is a priority for all those who can influence the decision makers in Stormont to deliver for the local community and that there is nothing more important than health care.In addition, campaigners believe that the New Decade New Approach document presents the local community with both opportunities and challenges and that there could potentially be threats to health services.They say any proposed changes to services which will not improve upon what is already in place will be vigorously resisted.Community health committee chairman, Mr Eamonn McGrady, said campaigners were not resisting change and recognised that modernisation was important, including new technologies and services.He also believes that there are opportunities for local services moving forward.Recently published figures have revealed that the number of acute beds across Northern Ireland have fallen dramatically over the past seven years and more, with calls for more bed provision in the Downe Hospital.Campaigners say that the reduction in bed numbers provides further evidence of what is already obvious to many that less beds is leading to longer patient waiting times across the health service.Confirming that campaigners are seeking a meeting with the new man in charge of the Stormont health portfolio, Mr McGrady said that while Mr Swann will receive many similar requests, local campaigners are keen to speak with him.He said that while there will inevitably be much debate about hospital provision moving forward, there is a recognition that there is a duplication of services in some areas.He said the idea that people may have to travel a little further to a specialist unit to get whatever procedure they require is something that they will live with and understand.Mr McGrady continued: ldquoThe reality is that the Downe has already suffered all the pain. It has been downgraded to a Type II emergency unit which we believe is not sufficient. The Downe was only one of two hospitals in the past  years which had had its needs fully assessed before it was built.ldquoThere is a clearly established case for a -hour emergency service in Downpatrick operating seven days a week and nothing has happened at the Department of Health or anywhere  to suggest otherwise. Service changes were made in the past due to staffing issues, nothing .Mr McGrady also revealed that changes are planned at the Downe with surveyors visiting the hospital recently to examine where the proposed new MRI scanner will be located.He said the provision of the scanner will result in an extension being built and also open the door to allow the hospital to do so much more in terms of diagnostics and other opportunities,Campaigners also insisted at last weekrsquos meeting that space is needed to reopen  beds closed in the same week of the new Downersquos official opening in , highlighting the need for everyone mdash including politicians and Newry, Mourne and Down Council mdash to work together on this particular issue and that it was time for the ldquoinjustices of the past in terms of local health care provision to be addressed.Mrs Anne Trainor highlighted the lack of investment in local hospital services in the past and said it was time that the Downe Hospital was firmly on the ldquolips of the decision makers and that the local area got its fair share of funding.Looking to the future, she saidthe Downe does become a centre of excellence for the elderly, this will pave the way for other new services to add to those already in place.She also backed calls for more beds to be provided in the Downpatrick hospital and is keen to see the local council taking an active role on health and working alongside campaigners.ldquoHealth is the single most important issue and we have been hammering home this message for years, she declared.ldquoNewry, Mourne and Down Council needs to play a serious role in the delivery of healthcare. The former Down Council put its hands in its pocket to help the hospital campaign but its successor has been lacking in this regard.Mrs Trainor added: ldquoWe want a fully ing hospital that provides this community with the services it needs. We already have an excellent hospital and fantastic staff, but the community deserves what everyone  has.ldquoWe also need to to engage with local medical providers who are the experts. They have the knowledge and the experience and we have the voice and we should work together for the common good..prettyPhoto

title: Motorists wait on MoT dates
story: MOTORISTS across the district whose vehicles require an MoT test are waiting to hear when the inspections will go ahead.On Monday evening, the Driver and Vehicle Agencyconfirmed that vehicle tests at all MoT centres across the province mdash including the Cloonagh Road facility in Downpatrick mdash have been suspended in the wake of mounting concern after cracks were discovered in vehicle lts.Speculation is mounting that the suspension could remain in place for weeks or possibly months, but checks on buses and heavy goods vehicles will continue as these vehicles are inspected using a dedicated viewing area which is below ground level.DVA chief executive Paul Duffy confirmed that the contractor responsible for repairing the vehicle lts has ldquonot provided sufficient assurance to DVA on the effectiveness of the ongoing repairs.As a result, he said tests had been suspended ldquoto ensure the health and safety of staff and customers. He also confirmed that drivers due to have tests yesterday, except those with four-year-old vehicles and taxis, would be automatically issued with an MoT exemption certicate and can continue to drive.The exemption will be recorded in the DVA system and a hard copy will arrive by post in the coming days.The DVA says that all customers, except customers with four year old vehicles and taxis, will be automatically issued an MoT exemption certicate and therefore can continue to drive with staff working urgently to find a solution to get owners of four year old vehicles and taxis through the MoT.In a statement yesterday morning, the DVA said that it recognised the ldquoconsiderable inconvenience and disruption this will cause for many people and apologised that it has been unable to recty this situation more quickly.Mr Duffy said the DVA will directly contact customers with four-year-old vehicles and taxis and are ldquoworking to urgently find a solution to get these vehicles through MoT.He continued: ldquoThe DVA will issue a further statement as a matter of urgency to advise these customers and those who have MoTs booked for later this week. We want to advise customers that more cancellations are very likely.Mr Duffy apologised for the ldquoconsiderable inconvenience and disruption this will cause for many people and said that given the urgency of the situation, the DVA is asking the public to follow media, social media channels and nidirect for updates..prettyPhoto

title: New children’s play therapy centre opens in Downpatrick
story: A NEW childrenrsquos play therapy facility has opened in Downpatrick.Run by Laura Downey, the new service is located above the Le Change, Changes Lives base in Market Street.Laura mdash who volunteers with the charityrsquos hugely popular Pop Up Art initiative which upscales old furniture mdash is delighted to be working locally, providing a service which can help children with emotional behavioural problems.She operates in a dedicated room which includes a range of furniture she purchased from Le Change, Changes Lives which is designed to help children feel at home. In addition to her work with children, Laura is also keen to show her support for the work carried out by the charity.Explaining the nature of her work, Laura said that it centres around helping children deal with emotional behavioural problems through play.She has a dedicated toolkit to help which includes sand trays, miniature toys, stuffed toys, hand puppets and books containing therapeutic stories to help deliver the so-called Play  Grow project.A qualied play therapist who is registered with Play Therapy UK, Laura has been working with children since  and previously spent time working in Downpatrick where she did her voluntary placement with Action for Children based at the Ballymote Centre.She explained that the opportunity to set up her new service came about as a result of her volunteering work with Le Change Changes Lives, with her work focusing on children aged between four and .ldquoI work with children who have emotional behavioural problems, those dealing with bereavement and loss or who have separated or orced parents, Laura continued.ldquoI also work with those who have anger of anxiety issues, those who may have become withdrawn, have communication problems or have suffered forms of abuse or nightmares. I also work with those who are being bullied or who are bullies themselves.Laura, who offers a free consultation with parents, said children can release their inner feelings through play.She explained that play is a childrsquos natural medium of self expression, highlighting the number of times children ask their parents to play with them and have a chat. Laura said children feel most comfortable in this environment.ldquoAs play is what children are comfortable with, it makes sense that you would use this method to help them through a dficult time. This is particularly effective for children who cannot or who do not want to talk about their problems.ldquoThey can play out their feelings and problems anda child wants to talk to me here of course they can do that. Some children say that they do not want to talk about whatever trauma is in their lives and I say to them that is great because they do not have to.ldquoHowever, they will still express those feelings through play and may in fact not be aware that this is what they are doing. The metaphor is very powerful in the play therapy room and children can hide behind a mask to demonstrate their feelings and using a puppet is a very good example of that.Laura said her work is a method of helping children with behavioural and emotional problems to help themselves, explaining that is the children do all the work.ldquoI am just here as a facilitator, she said. ldquoPlay therapy is not always fun and sometimes the children will encounter dficult feelings. I adopt a child-centred approach where the child leads the way and the therapist follows which is non directive.ldquoOne of the most important aspects of play therapy is the element of control. For some children when something has happened in their le or environment it is a thing which they cannot control which causes trauma. When they come here, this is the one place they can come in and say lsquoright we are doing this my wayrsquo and it can take back control.Laura described play therapy is ldquonon judgemental and said children know they are in a safe environment and can express themselves in any way in which they will be accepted or who they are.She added: ldquoThe children will learn that while here they can be themselves and they will feel comfortable to be themselves.Laura can be contacted on   or via her social media page..prettyPhoto

title: New minister at Lissara church
story: A NEW chapter in the history of Lissara Presbyterian Church opened last weekend with the installation of the Rev Alan Burke.A large congregation attended last Friday eveningrsquos service in Crossgar with the new minister looking forward to his time working in the area.For the past two and a half years, Mr Burke was assistant minister at the Loanends and Killead churches near Aldergrove. In Crossgar, he succeeds the Rev Ian Abraham, who was in charge at Lissara since December .Mr Burke said he was ldquodelighted to take up his new ministry and is looking forward to settling into the local community with his we Allison and three young children.Born and bred in the village of Articlave, near Coleraine, the new minister brings with him a wealth of knowledge.He continued: ldquoI am delighted to finally take up my first ministry at Lissara Presbyterian Church which has been the culmination of a lot of hard work and effort. It feels like I have come home.Mr Burke began studying at Belfastrsquos Union Theology College several years ago, explaining that a minister must spend two years in study and train for a further five before he can be ordained.Mr Burke, who attended Dunboe First Presbyterian as a child, explained that it wasnrsquot until he was  that he felt the inner sense of call to the faith.He added: ldquoWhen I grew up the church was more for lsquowomen and wainsrsquo than it was for young people or men in general, but circumstances led me to my faith.ldquoMy hope is that my family and I will be in Crossgar for many years..prettyPhoto

title: Red High march past Cardonagh
story: THE MacLarnon Cup holders secured their place in the quarter-finals of the competition with an impressive victory over Cardonagh at Faughanvale last Wednesday afternoon.However, St Patrickrsquos, Downpatrick, had to do it the hard way after losing influential half forward Dermot Donaldson midway through the first half.The Red High juggernaut was in full flow by this stage and had taken a - to - lead when Donaldson saw red.That moved to - to - by the break with Eoin Rooney and Lorcan Guinness lording Carndonagh in defence.Tom Smyth, in midfield and Odhran Sherry, in a free role around the middle, picked up a lot of possession and distributed it well with Chris McElroy, Tom Savage, Smyth and Ronan Connorregistering a string of points to put them in command of the tie.Carndonagh struggled to make an impression on the game and relied totally on frees from Luke Doherty and Tiernan McDonald to keep in touch.They were edging a little closer midway through the second half when the key moment arrived with Christopher McDaid put through one-on-one with Peter Kearney. But the big Downpatrick net-minder was up to the task and saved.That would have levelled the tie and the momentum gained might have swung it Carndonaghrsquos way. Instead Downpatrick got their second wind and the game was put to bed five minutes from time when Tom Smyth race through to find the net.It turned out to be a great day for Downpatrick with De La Salle High School, who share a site with St Patrickrsquos, edging an extra time thriller with Colaacuteiste Oiriall in the Danske Bank Ward Cup.De La Salle led by - to - towards the end of normal time, but conceded four points in a row and the game went into extra time.Cathal Lavertyrsquos goal gave De La Salle a single point advantage at half-time and a strike from Con Farrell put them two points up at the death with Oiriall awarded a  metres free in added time.The shot was beaten out and over the bar for Downpatrick to make it through to the next round on a - to - scorelineSt Patrickrsquos: Peter Kearney, Eoin Rooney, Lorcan Guiness, Caolan Murray, Odhran Barlow, Aodan Harney, Tom Smyth , Oran Cunningham, Conor Murray, Tom Savage , Ronan Connor , Dermot Donaldson, Chris McElroy , Tom McNeill -, Odhran Sherry. title: Shimna College leads way in cultural event
story: A NEWCASTLE school which is at the forefront of a new initiative to help forge a better understanding of German culture has been given a double seal of approval.Stormont First Minister Arlene Foster and the deputy German ambassador, Julia Gross, were full of praise for Shimna Integrated College when they visited the school last Thursday.Shimna College is the first school in Northern Ireland to sign up for the PASCH-Schule initiative which provides many opportunities for students.School principal Kevin Lambe explained: ldquoBeing involved in the PASCH initiative is tremendously important for all of us in Shimna College.ldquoUnder the Specialist Schools Programme, we were the first specialist school for languages in Northern Ireland and we are constantly striving to broaden all our studentsrsquo horizons through German and our other languages.ldquoThe PASCH Initiative has already provided opportunities for our students and staff to experience German language and culture in a iety of ways including a football scholarship in Hamburg, an engineering internship with Mercedes-Benz in Koblenz and robotics training for staff.Mr Lambe continued: ldquoWe look forward to being networked with other schools in the PASCH Initiative, sharing experiences and ideas and we look forward to the further promotion of closer links with Germany.ldquoWe do all this under the celebration of cultural ersity which is a central part of our integrated ethos.ldquoFor some reason in Northern Ireland, learning German has traditionally been hived off as something only the most able can study and usually as an extra, but in Shimna, learning German is open to everyone who chooses.Mrs Foster said the initiative provided a ldquonew and exciting opportunity for the young people at Shimna College to immerse themselves in the language, ideas and culture of another country.ldquoAs we enter a new decade, it has never been more important for our pupils to have an international perspective and to embrace the opportunities presented through initiatives such as these.ldquoThrough this programme, pupils are building connections that will help create jobs. They are sharing knowledge and best practice in tackling some of the many global challenges we face today.ldquoIt is a pleasure to have the opportunity to both enjoy these celebrations and indeed to visit the school here in Newcastle.Ms Gross told her audience: ldquoAs language students and teachers at Shimna College you all hold the key to a peaceful and rich future and have a crucial part to play, especially in the coming months and years as Brexit unfolds.ldquoYou are the bridge builders and communicators of tomorrow."Judging from your school motto ndash learning from each other ndash the spirit of solidarity and friendship is already firmly rooted in your schoolrsquos DNA.She added: ldquoYour language skills will help ensure our countries remain close neighbours, good friends and vital partners..prettyPhoto

title: Tasty double for Gainford
story: THE East Down Foxhounds got the spring point-to-point season underway in cold, but dry conditions at David Corbettrsquos Tyrella estate on Saturday.Despite the cold, the meeting drew the largest attendance in years and also the biggest entry for the January meeting at the long-established venue.One man who will long remember the meeting is young Wexford jockey Jordan Gainford as he recorded his first ever double mdash it is also worth noting that his two winners under rules have come at Downpatrick and Down Royal.It was also a good day for Templepatrick owner trainer Warren Ewing, both his winners being ridden by Gainford.The first of these came in the second race of the day, the Armstrong Auctions  year-old geldings race. Gainford rode Only the Bold, who his owner described as a very good horse, to a nine- success over Tommyrsquos Oscar, ridden by Barry OrsquoNeil with Il Courra and Simon Cavanagh a short head back in third.All the Best, trained by Paddy Turley, was ridden by Ben Harvey after Declan Laverty decided to ride another horse in the race.The second winner for the duo came in the FC Herron six year-old plus geldings race that saw  go to post, the largest line out of the day.Here, Gainford made every post a winning one on the Great White, running for the third time, to come home as he pleased,  s clear of Parkgate, ridden by Noel McParlan in Ronnie Bartlettrsquos colours with Loughhill and Stephen Connor third mdash ahead of the much-raced and luckless, after  runs, Airdrigh.Closest finish of the day came in the Irish National Hunt steeplechase committee six year-old and upwards maresrace with only a nose separating the first two past the judge, Peter Stewart, with Any Time, back in third, ahead of newcomer Drumconnor Road.Over the final fence, Cave Queen, who had been in the lead for some time, was challenged by bank official Aileen OrsquoSullivan on Deo Bellator, owned and trained by her father, Denis.A photo-finish was called for before Cave Queen and Paul Bannon were declared winners to loud cheers.Bannon later got a one-day ban for his frequency with the whip mdash the best finish in a local point-to-point in years.Peter Flood, who has made a big name for himself as a handler in recent seasons, trained the winner for his mother, Teresa.All bar two of the  entries took part in the first race of the day, the Albert Bartlett race for five-year old mares. Here, Thump Lady and Tipperary jockey Pa King, made the early running with Tango Theatre, in Warren Ewingrsquos colours, taking over.However, she was headed in the closing stages by Aprilrsquos Joy in the well known red and yellow silks of Co Meath owner breeder, Denis Reddan, his first win in some time, ridden by Ben Harvey.The winner is trained by Co Meath-based Gavin Cromwell, who can train winners at all levels of the sport. Thrump Lady kept on well to take third.The Patrick Turley Kingsfield Stables open race saw an excellent turnout of  runners out of the  entries taking part with victory, as expected, going to Eddiersquos Miracle, already a winner twice this season for the in-form duo of Belfast bookie Ray Nicholas and Derrylin trainer David Christie.Ridden by Barry OrsquoNeil, the combination won from the Jim Dreaper-trained Rob James-ridden Sizing Solotin with Mad Jack Mytton and Peter Kavanagh third mdash this was a thwin between the flags for the winner.The East Downrsquos next meeting is due at Tyrella on March , but the next local meeting will be held at Kirkistown.The best turned out in all races was courtesy of Glencairn Stables.The East Downrsquos annual hunt ball will take place on February  in thesuite at Downpatrick racecourse. Tickets for the black tie event can be obtained from hunt members at pound.A notable absentee on Saturday was mounted steward Declan Feeney, currently on the injured list, also missed was Kelvin Henderson, following a recent illness.Race organisers would like to thank Downpatrick Racecourse for use of equipment and help prior to the meeting.Sympathy is extended to Turf Club official and assistant trainer Leo Gracey on the recent death of his father, Jack.Photographer Harry Marcus was welcomed back to action at Tyrella following a hip operation..prettyPhoto

title: Work in place to revamp planning
story: WORK on a major new initiative to improve key aspects of the districtrsquos planning service is underway.An expert planning consultant from Wales is working alongside Newry, Mourne and Down Council planners to enhance the current service, with the focus on quicker turnaround times for applications and getting on top of outstanding enforcement cases.Figures recently made public by the local authority reveal that there are just over  live planning applications in the system and  live enforcement cases.Between April and December last year, just over , new applications were lodged with local planners with the average number of applications per case officer standing at  at the end of the year. Last May, the figure was  per planner.Previously, planning was the responsibility of the local authorityrsquos Regulatory and Technical Services Committee but it now operates under the umbrella of the Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee which senior council officials insist makes more sense.Officials say that planning has been evolving over the past number of years and is not only a key aspect of the local authorityrsquos operation, but essential to the regeneration and development of the district.Council officials and planners are working in tandem with the planning consultant to improve a service which they hope can become the best of its kind in the Province.The work to improve the service is fully supported by local planners who carried out their own internal review several months ago and who want to enhance the service across what is Northern Irelandrsquos third largest council area.Senior council officials view planning as a key driver to the districtrsquos successful regeneration and economic development and want to demonstrate that the Newry, Mourne and Down area is open for business.They believe that turning planning applications around in a timely manner can act as a catalyst to encourage developers to invest in the district.Moving forward, enforcement of illegal development is high on the priority list, with the council aiming to demonstrate that planners can deal with all manner of applications efficiently to send out a positive message to the construction industry and developers in particular.Council officials say that there is a commitment, willingness and appetite among planning staff to do better which they are in fact doing and confirmed that they also plan to talk to planning agents across the district about the work that is ongoing.Local authority officials say that previous reviews have identied what the issues are within planning, with the current exercise dealing with the challenges and implementing change.They insist that the planning service it is responsible for will improve once all the issues have been addressed and resolved and paid tribute to the hard work and commitment of all planning staff.A Newry, Mourne and Down Council spokesman confirmed that the organisationrsquos planning department has employed the services of a professional planning advisor.He explained the advisorrsquos role is to identy and implement improvements to the performance of the department in both planning enforcement and development management.ldquoThis work will focus on examining and streamlining the existing processes within theby introducing more efficient procedures, said the spokesman.He added: ldquoIt will also focus on introducing basic performance management, regular casework appraisals and improving sign-off procedures..prettyPhoto
